titleStmt.title: CW 126f
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

change.item: Added new Encoding and Profile Descriptions
Proof-read this file and made corrections

div.title: Burns
div.p:
From Angus Macniven tailor
Cill Taigh an Uillt aged
Tuesday 25 July 1892

Some two hundred ago
there lived a man at Bail-an-deor
of the name of Campbell
He was called Fear Bhail-an-Deor and
Caimbeulach Bhail or indis
criminate He was a man of great
natural parts gifted ready-witted and
a bard but of fierce by nature.

One day sixteen men came to his
house – it is not known for what
purpose only that to those
that it was otherwise than kindly
Campbell had
in place of his called Glac-a-
Chlamhain – the hollow of the hawk.
Probably there were hawks. He had
splitting and wedge in
cut off the heads of the whole
helpless men
and indignation got in got up
throughout the district
and in consequence of the murdered
men Campbell fled the country
and never returned. It was in

The ) Duncan Macniven old
schoolmaster Cnoc na h Aird
Taynuilt 6th July 1892

The Ceathirne-ChoillCeathairne-Choill came
the way. They would not have
you if you gave them enter
tainmtentertainment if not they took of your
stock. Fear Bhail an deor had a
sail dharaich and he was splitting
up – He placed 8 on each side
and killed them all – with the sword.
16 of the ceithirn choill – because
they dwelt in woods.

div.title: Iain Lom
div.p:
The Crunair came once a year
to levy dues on those who dis
tilled bitter spirits:– Campbell of
Glasaruith in KillmhichKillmhicheil
There is also Killimhicheil Iner
Lusa) His wife was a Mac Cal
man of from Barriglas, Glen-
lonain. His wife complained
that the cruner was rude to her
when he came the way. Don-
ald Campbell hid himself on the
faradh and when he saw the
cruner misbehaving to his wife
he came down and drove his
biodag throthrough him. Campbell
fled north & stayed not till he was
in Keppoch. The wife was with
child & the child was seven years
ere she heard that her husband
was alive Came she to Barra-glass
where her people – MacCalmans
were living & she lived with
them. Then she & her boy went
to Keppoch & her husband the
man Campbell already
became a Macdonald –
Donald Campbell lived in
Glen a ghlasarai. He made
himself Mac-a-ghlasaraich.

lg.l: Saighead as an Dha bheith an Doir-dhonn

div.p:
Doire donn in Glenorch.Glenorchy
He thinks Baile na Gailbhinn –
that the string came from here.
Calpa na craoibh = trunk of the tree.

Iain Beag Mac a Chombaich
12 cli-sheanachaincliar-sheanachain – had to get
a stirk a calf or cow killed.

An Deor mor Mac a Chombaich
was the man of Baile an Deoir

Cnoc-aingil = Cnoc a Charra
Cnoc-"Cnoc-anigil Ru-nan-carn – Where
the manse of Aird Chattain.
Cnoc-aingil at Cillachrianain
Dun-cliathaich Dun-chaoich
Loch chrianan Port Sonanich
Dun-chuaich – these were lighted
Invering Dun-beag – These were
lighted on danger = danger
Iain Lom seven years ere he walked

Deor mor Mac an aba
was the name of the --- deor of Bail-an-deor
SgiaSgiath ime sclaisclaidheamh caise

Tradition says that Lochetive
was a lake. A narrow isthmus of
of of gravelly soil separated
the sea from the lake at Connel –
During a great storm and high tide
the sea made an inroad through
this gravelly bank that divided
separated the sea from the lake.
The water of the lake rushed throthrough
carrying the friable isthmus before
it. The isthmus stood where the
Falls of Lora are now.

The Campbells Smiths of Bun
awe a native of Perthshire and
apprentice smith to smiths in
Kilmartin. His master got jealous
of him for his adhart – tempering –
binding a sword to hilt. Fled from
Kilmartin. Came to Bunawe.

lg.l: Bean na suisuidhe air an lar
Bonnaich gheala gan ri cur ri cloich
A bhonaid mhor ann air a tnsatsnath
Chan eil i siud air a ghlun

div.p:
Bera went to see Cailleach
Bheur Erin & stayed too long
ceilidh. When she came back
the lid of the well was off & Loch
awe the result. Then she sang

Iseabal ninic RaoilRaghnaill datdaughter of
Ranald Macdonald died
at house of ArchArchibald Morrison
Snaoesval long over 100 when
she died in 1866. Had all her
faculties – 100 to 120 when she died.
She was taken by Flora as a dilean
on her return from America.

Aber-tibirt at the head of Loch
tiacais. Morven.
Tobar-thibert = Smeircleit.

St Cyrill preached the gospel in
Bute & Argile.

div.title: Maceachains
div.p:
(1) Neill Maceachain the son
of Hector son John son Hector
son of John son of Alexander son
of John ic RaoilRaghnaill, from Arasaig
– the first from Arasaig to How
beag.

(2) Neill Maceachan son
of Alexander son of John son
of Ranald from Arasaig.
Aa Alexander father of the
Marshall head Neill father
of the Marshal had Neill
Ranald Howbeag. He is the
first called of Howbeg.

RaolRaghnaill had Alexander
who was called Alexander
Mor Howbig. This Alastair
had daughters (4).
and several illegitimate daughters.
Alexander Mor called himself
Macdonald probprobably after his cousin
the Marshal – all the others
kept to Maceachains -

Neil, Ranald, John & Angus
Ranald being the father of Alas
tair Mor – the father of the Marshall.
RaoilRaghnaill Howbeg this RaolRaghnaill being
the first called of Howbeag
RaoilRaghnaill had no son except Alastair
Mor.
Born at Frobost.

The Prince came to her brotherbrother's
house Airi-mhuilinAiridh-mhuilinn bial anamoch
na h oicheoidhche. Sat on a stone near
the house a messenger wenwent in for
Flora who came out – Probably
planned by Boisdale). The fire
was on the middle of the floor. He
went in & got food. Hugh Macdonald
commandcommanded the cordon
guarding Faothail Ormacleit.
Loch Olaidh ran west between
Ormacleit & Stoney-brig – south of
Cladh Mhicheil at Aird
Mhicheil. This ford dangerous
from quick sand from Iurdain
A high ridge of sand ran along
here – so high that the shore
could not be seen from OrmaclOrmacleit.
Hugh Macdonald gave a pass
to through the cordon at Faothail
Ormacleit – F.Faothail Bhan.
Neill Maceachain was sent
for to interpret.

At FFaoghail Hough the soldiers wanted
to catch the pristpriest. They questioned
the people. They searched. Capt Campbell
went to the priest house at Kill
donan & saw the vestments with
the priest. He put on the alb
Next day he was found dead in
the hill. WhereWhether shot be his own headhand or
anothers is uncertain. He was after
deer & game.

The hunt at Howmore Faoghail Hough – a woman told that the
priest was to pass to batisingbaptising a
child. When the priest came
the officer recogrecognised him & caught
him by the wrist & lifted up his pistol
You are my prisoner. The priest
seized him by the wrist so that the pistol
fell from the officer. The officer
admired the priest & said It is a
pity you wear that cloth – Is
bocbochd thu bhi san deise. Pass up
and down unmolested while I am
in command. The informer
got a 6d Mo Dhia s mo 6d was
contantlyconstantly in his mind. From
remorse. The priest's name
was – Macdonald –
He passed the Creagorry cordon
unobserved.
Made their way to Roisnis
where l.lord l.lady ClanraldClanranald found them
From there they sailed. The AiriAiridh
of ClanrnldClanranald where a boat was
waiting there.

George Munro died in 1852
aged 91 born 1714 1741.
Over 60 years there. His father
John Munro was minminister there and
lived at Killabhain – AftAfter mitminister
of Duirinish Skye.

Hugh Maceachan got an old
woman to come to church of SScotland he
placed her on horse back on bag of wilkswhelks
made noise with wilkswhelks – horse
ran away – old woman fell & broke
her leg. The other member was an
old Uistean was half brother
to John Maceachan to John Mac
eachain to whom the marshal
gave the £30 – John had learned
to be a tailor – and not work at this
Then he learndlearned to be joiner under
Ruairi Saor. then merchant -
He died worth 3000£.

Alasdair Mor & his cousin the
Marshal stodstood side by side and
were alike in height and appearappearance
ruddy high cheek bones – both tall.
(John Macaulay ministminister lived
at Killipheadair)

GeoGeorge Munro born at Killvarait
ClanraldClanranald in passing throthrough Skye
asked John Munro what favour he
could do him. the ministminister told him t
o give S.South Uist to his son George.
This John showed kindness
to Father RanldRanald Maceachen
who was ship wrecked in Skye
coming home with church finding
vestments. Shaken &c.
All lost – save the men who
climbed up rocks – They saw a
light which claimed to be the
ministerminister's light. It was a miracle
they were saved. The minstminister showdshowed
much kindness to the priest
This RanldRanald was a talented man
and a poet but died after
from the exposure. He was of
the Howbeag Maceachains
– very promising young man.
MacCodrum came to see
him.

lg.l: Is ioma rud a chunna mi riamh
Is tha mi riariamh fo bha mi og
S e sgriobh le ite geoigeoidh

div.p:
Is tustusa tha sidsiod Mhic Codrum
jumping up to greet him

Father RandRanald resided with his
father at Howbeag. Died in 1803
comparatively young.
The minisminister said F.Father RandRanald and
his compcompanion sent to Uist & showdshowed
them great kindness.

FrFather RanRanald Maceachain secsecrelty Scotu
chronicled – Catholic Church
of Scotland – appendix – pro
bably(?) a nephew of the Marshal
A priest Allan Macdon
ald who accompaccompanied the Prince
through all wrote an accaccount
at Rome – in M.S.
the M.S. lost.

Sgath na Nathrach ort a bheist
said one woman to another who was
heavy with child. The woman died
& the child.

Creag Rusgain on Fearnach farm
Clann Rusgain

Goirtean Chonasglaidh
Goirtean Conaisg part of Bail-
an-deor. The O in Conaisg is open
like o in wol

Starneal comes up L-etiveLoch-etive on
Bealtan Eve regularregulary. Two men
crossing at RuRubha nan carnan. What
do you sawsee Iain Bhain.
A little ban bird wt went up last
night & sdsailed betbetween here before
either of you said the portar.

Sliochd nam 60 buraiburraidh
Dhoirt am fuil air Sliabh an tuim

'Is iomhanionmhainn leis gach neach
a choltas.' Cha neil sin fior – chuir
mi da chaill a null s bu chol
tach ri chul iad s bha iad suil
a chul a mach or Iain Ban PortPortair.

An Laidhail chruaichruaidh chreagach
Baile is leibidich am {Mucarn{Mucarn

Guala Chrosda
Cille bhoidheach Cill Chaoireall
Is ioma colan gun cheann
Theid a Chill Chaoireall
See DunDuncan Clerk

lg.l: Theid Muc a chriarach sa rideire
Is niar ar fear a leagas

div.p:
These were na Sasanaich
Na h eich mhaide = vessels
G.Guala C.Chrosda used to speak to himself
& people listedlistened

Thuradh e s cha d rinn e
a building that was to be put up –
but nevnever put up.

CaillCailleach Phabsach dhubh wldwould
put it on fire LLoch nell Castle

Theid drochadrochaid an Atha s cha bu
drochdrochaid an Atha – bridge fell
& a tailor just got over bridgbridge

An Deora Mor Mac an Aba of
Bail an deor. Mac a Chombaich
Ardanyle Leacan Mhic a
Chombaich in Ardenny.

18 families in Balandeor now 4 only
BBaile an Deor ten miles from Taighan uillt.

lg.l: Do thiolthiodlacadh bo dom chaidh a bh an

div.p:
The feallain were in DunDuncan CambellCampbell
s feet Burnside – bha e strocach
bacach.

Cabhuil = Stone dyke to go across a stream
If one small opening left throthrough which fish go
The coinnichleachadh is drivgdriving

Cha neil dion an sgrobsgriob na
Caimbeulaich – false!

Calum dudubh na tuaigh stole a
cow from L.Loch nell while in
Achna crei beag.

CathCatherine LivgLivingtone dautdaughter of DonDonald LivgLivingstone
Farm Bailimor Kerrara. This
DonDonald grandgrandfather of my father. She marmarried
DonDonald LivgLivingstone of Ulva. She was g mother
of Neill fathfather of David LivgLivingstone

My fathfather ArchArchibald L.Livingstone went to see
his aunt to Blantyre. He saw
Neil fathfather of David. Some of them
chilchildren of DonDonald had their fingers
adting – I am the only one
of these Livingstones. Neill LLivingstone
at Boness. SanitSanitoriumInsptInspector.
Another relative.

Achnacri Beag
The had feacfeachd mor dhaoine
came to Ach na cri mor & beg
gave the shells in a bag. The men
clndcleaned away all spoils. Lochnell
sent for LivgLivingstone you will be hanged
The man fled. I am {innocent uncertain
where I am this or those of
LivingLivingstone. They had LivingLivingstone funfound
Giallachadh = Hiding 4 Oct.October 921892.

Port na crois
Livingstones of Achancries had Dail
An-eas. In 1400 Livingstone of Achna
cri killed a deer for the King with
an arrow. The deer went to the Glen
coe frith & ththe Glen coe men were
on the watching & seized the LingLivingstone. They
were going to kill him but sent home
his son for the coraichean. The corcoraichean
came & he lost Dail an eas to the
Macdonalds. This from John
LivingstonLivingstone mac Chaillein mac
Dhonnacha mac Dhun-sleibhe
Mac DonnachaiMac Dhonnachaidh

Mart bradach put on the fair
adh of LivingLivingstone of Achnacri. Seach
was made &.

The baron who brotbrought boats of Tigh
earna na h Apann was killed by
Macleans of Duart while out
fishing. TighTighearna na h Appan
is buried in Lismore.

Two of the chairs of Statean at
Locheitive
Sile = Generation

Scott was teaching at Illanahairi
no relation. In Gleann na h-aile

Clann ic an LeLeigh nam busa
gorma – Baron of Bachaill.
Baran nam busa gorma

Bachuill Wednesday 5 OctOctober 1892
Appin & his man went to Duart
When all were at Games, AppAppin man
bestbested & thrashed the Macleans then battle
and AppsAppin's man killed. Nach ann air
tha n t saill said they Chan ann air
faochfaochagan an chladchladaich bha mo ghille sa
beo idir said AAppin The taunt was so
true to the Maclean that they fell upon
AAppin & killed him. They hung up his body
against the castle and defied the world
to touch it. The B.Baron of BBachuill heard what ococcured
to his proproprietor and he and his two red haired
fine datdaughters went to Duart. rendrendered all
the boats useless. One big birlin last
Got boybody of AppAppin. Missed. Chased. Boat
after boat leaks. Then fell upon the
big birlinn & was heavy. Oars broken
& cut arr across. Gave chase got
up at Musdale. Baron crossed the
caolscaolas the others with Is minig thainig fior a fanaid
body buried in Port chailleach
in shingle. Taken up buried in church.
This privprivilege given to Baron for what he
had done. Baron killed after by a
shot from Duart.

DonDonnchadh Pharuig
uncan Macniven 88 Aird tells that
dogs go away from home when about
to die. This is known to shepherds and
when the old dogs are absent they
know they go away to die.

A man at {Glenoe Glenoe went to a {site {situation in
in England. He left his dog in his home.
Every day the dog went out at the
same time saw and cried and wept & at last
he died.
ClanClann ic Ille naoimh

DuntanDuntanachan lam Barra glas
Am Scuil 's Barr-an-Eas and all the rest
Lon a chorain 's Barra Goillean
S BealBealach Chreag Mac-Righ

This said by a lady who was in a town be
sieged in the Peninsular War. She
put her head over a window.

Creag Mac RiRigh UsenchedUisneach
Bealach Creag Mac Righ, Aird
enry farm. See the heads on CladCladh
na mac RiRigh (3 heads cut in stone.

A man lived at Baile Taigh beallach
RuaiRuaidh who {wrote {wrote with in ogham – He
had no letters but made certain notches
which his wife understood. Uilleam
Swain.

lg.l: Fear a shiulshiubhail o dheas gu tuatuath
S cha rorobh fios co dhiu b fhearb fhearr

Ach thug e n t-urram a dh-fhan
na mocheiridh.
Sa mhaol oarodhar na h im

div.p:
Uisge Chille at Cillichnap {Cill-a-chreanain
coming down frfrom Loch Liona
Troma-li to Lochaw.

Maol odhar at Fearnach
Lochawe side.

7 sons of Kings said to be burburied at
Cladh na Mac RiRigh. Also Bille

Choinnich = edge of stream?
Cille-Choinnich
Don.Donald DhonuillDhomhnuill (Sinclair)

Hoggs Instrutor vol VI New
Series 1851 page 185 See Oban Express of May
or April 92

lg.l: Far a bheil an t-or am falfalach

S chachan fhaifhaigh e ach a ni mhaol
charrach

div.p:
This place is at Fearnoch
Muckairn

Also ulla at Coille bheag close
to Cill, Bunawe. This wawas a beautifbeautiful
oak wood of rare beauty. Now supsupplanted by
pine. Round marable stones got
at Ru-aird-an-draighin at
Beinn-duirenis. A queen from
Ireland came there. She fled with
a man – ruins visible near
Eilean Uisneachain.

Caisteal Dun-Meirgeall at
Iocar-achann – ath-chumhain

div.title: Eireireadh -

lg.l: S gad bhiodh i pronnadh cuirce

div.p: Se Donallach a sin bhann ainmeil

Round stone 9 x 1½ deep. No one
will get the ulla till nighean
dughdubh a Chlann ic niamhan
said Guala Chiosda. Polished
on both sidesides

Bera the herdess eura was the guardian angel of Ben Cruachan
She went to ceilidh to Neibhis the
herdess of Beinn Neubhis. She
stayed too long "air cheilidh
gossipping and when she re-
turned home to her own mount
ain of Cruachan she found
that the lid of the well was
off which had been given
her to guard and and keep
Cruachan Beann was pour
ing out and Bera could only
look on and weep. Lochawe =
Loch-odha was the result.
There Bera wept her fill
and said

lg.l: S mi fo mhulad ri tuiream

S mi air shuidhe air mullach
Chruachan

div.p:
From Mr Dugald Clerk late of
Duntannachain. See Garnets
Tour

lg.l: A smiamh mo chuigeil taobh a bheinne
S mi ri tuiream an tuibir

div.p: Old Duncan Macniven, Aird

Dr. Donald Munro Morrison,
Son of Iain Gobha, Harris
died in No 22 Ward R.Royal Infirmary
Edinburgh on Monday the
2d DecDecember 1889 A.Alexander C.Carmichael

lg.l: S ioma fuil ard ga dioladh
Is caidcairdeach mi don chinne chleutach
S treubh na h ApanAppan mi
S iad nach islich an ceann
S iad a chuir an ruaig
'S iad e n cul so'n cul??

div.p:
see History of Stewarts of Appin
for the Baron and his two red haired
daughters.

John Livingstone son of L.Livingstone Ach
na crei went to Morvern his son Donald
fotfought at Culloden aged
18. Nine DonaldDonalds were shot
down dead carrying the Bratach of the
Prince when DonDonald Livingstone
took it up and swathed round
his body. He was shot down and
was thought to be dead but he got up
with nine bullet wounds –
fresh wounds which were seen
in his body when he died aged
79 or 80 years old. Never had
trews on. He was drover to George
being commissariat to the garri
son at F.Fort William as to to the
last. Died at Morvern. He
had six sons – two of whom
were drowned on Cuan
na h-Eirinn having a veselvessel of
their own with which they
traded to Ireland. There wewere
2 dats.daughters died unmarried.
Donald Molach – "hairy DondDonald"
He was called – in Savary.
His wife Jane Stewart of
Ardslignish. The mother
of Donull Molach was Ann
Macinnes native of Morvern

There are two Fionnars. FionFionnar
Bheag the manse on and F.Fionnar
mhor between F.Fionnar bheag and Samh
aire – the river Salachan be-
tween Kilundain & Glebe

DonDonald Molach brotbrot two horses
from Culloden one in each
hand – He gave one of these to James
a Ghlinne – Stewart of Glenure
whose ban He foughtfought under the banner
of the Stewarts and took up the flag

Saved the heir of Lochuie who
fell in the linne mhuillinn at
a dinner. DonDonald MolMolach jumedjumped
in and threw him up from the
bottom. Swam from Glen
borrodal to Dorlinn for a wager
put on his osain
Maisie Marjory } dat.daughter of Rob.Robert Bruce

see Celtic MagMagazine for AugAugust 1875
& Good Words for AugAugust 1882

C. H. Hucheson says that in S.South of Ireland
fires are lit by fisher-folks on 29th
June the Eve of S.S. Peter and Paul.

Spey-mouth 1664 May 15 Its
ordained that men cast fire into their
nets and if any should so that they
be considered as charmers.

Loch-li - – A pool on top of
the hill close to Eoligearry, Barra.
Its on this pool that the small
cockles grow mentioned by Martin.
A plant (vervain?) grows beside
the pool which the people say takes
off horse shoes!

Dullan water" in Aberdeen
shire is taulobh great dullan being
from dubh black and alan water black

Cadha Mor (2313 ftfeet high) is the name
of a high hill in Rothemuchras Fort).

Loch Coire an Lochain (3250) is the
highest and biggest tarn in Scoltand. It
is in Braeriach septseparating Aberdeen
and Inverness

lg.l: Cha fhreagair rud dur do'n fhear gheanail
No rud geanail do'n fhear dhubhach

div.p:
Prices for dressing skins of Yule
Tanner 25 Grassmarket EdinEdinburgh
Otter 1/6 Fox 1/6 to 2/- Cats 0/6 Roe 2/-
Deer 3/- to 4/- Fawn 1/6 to 2/-

Appointed to the Dean Distillery
(18th Station) on the 17th Oct 1893
took charge on the 23d OctOctober 1893.

Preface Perhaps someone may
exist with more learning and more
reason than mine to elucidate these
interesting obscurities

An Draidhean is a tidal
sgeir or rock near Salen Lismore
on the top of which there is a well
visible at half tide. Two miles or
so south west of this is Lith-sgeirLiath-sgeir
another tidal rock at some distance
from land – It is said that the
tomb stone of Iona, Lismore and
other places were quarried here –
In Lismore Iona and Inveraray
and other places a tombstone
is called Leac-lithe – the flag-stone
of Lithe or Li the flagstone of water
li – Draodhean is wren throm bull
but draoidh is a sculptor a
worker in stone – and there is an
island on Lochawe called
Eilean Inis nan Draodhean
Inis Draodhean – the isle of
the sculptors – wrongly called
Innis Druidhean isle of the
Druids. On Inis-ail lovely isle
near and the site of a Cistercian nun
arynunnery is a burgburying ground with probably
some of the loveliest sculptured
stones in all Britain. Now in
stead of Sgeir an Draoidhean
being called sgeir an Draoidhean
the sgeir of the sculptors. But
what should be the meaning?
Probably the same. Sgeir nan
Druidhean – sgeir of the sculpt
tors and Leithe Sgeir – sgeir of the
fountain have got transported
How or when I am unable to say
Inerchanged

No tool marks are now visible on Lith sgeirLiath sgeir
but the sculptors may have used fire
and water in quarrying the flags as the old men
of Uist used to do in removing the bouldice
ice blocks and boulders off their crofts

Lathacan = Laithgeann = Tir
Laidhgeann Lismore. Several
saints of this name. See 121p Book
of Hymns

Roban} Oide} = Foster father
Robag} Muime} = Foster father

Tart. "Tha tart air muinntir
anns an talamh." This was believed
of the old folks – that there were
creatures below who needed milk
cream or water if spilt. Hut
na canaibh guth – tha bial
feumach a feitheamh air
said an old man when his
wife spilt some milk on
the floor – ground.

Fionna-mheang = When pressed
out of chesset when set

Am Bra-lein = Bull, Am buth
ōmh ors am Bra-lein. Best bull of
fold

Fleothach = the young bull of the
fold - always on full of game
Fleaghach = a young man – fast.
Am bra-lin – table-cloth

Ciarachan = Murlag = the globe-
shaped basket in which the woman
kept wool. Some have bulgbulging chran-
in & hungup
Murlaig = clumsy person

Mamma burst a
blood vessel of the stomach
on the 3d of May 1896,
while in London. She
hovered between life and death
for several days. Even Sir
Lander Burnton said that
her case was very doubtful.
By degrees her case became
more hopeful and after
weeks she was able to be brought
home.

She and I travelled about
a good deal in Glencoe and
various other places enjoying
ourselves very much. We
returned home in
after a tour of
greatly refreshed.

Janet Buchanan, (Lagtothamh)
600 (?) Gallowgate, Glasgow
left side near Whitevale

Came then no letter no watch
God grant that she is well. Oh Mary
Mary if you knew my suffergsuffering
you would not thus treat me
I know! Must leave (DDeo vvolente on
Monday to meet her unable to en
dure this suspsuspence longer O God bring
me relief & comftcomfort to my troubled heart
"Thy foolish heart be still or break"
Mary Mary my ever darling
and devoted wife myhow do you thus
forget me?

7 Sunday. Went to hear Mr Clarke
Who preached (read) a good sermon (afraid
trifle too high for his hearers. Mr CClarke came up with
me & went to dinner & tea. I had to read
but couldn't. Felt wretched in the extreme
God grant yryour safe arrivarrival home my darling
wife – yryour silence and absence are the cause
of painful uneasiness & anxiety to me.
May He who allows not the sparrow to fall
unobserved nor the least of His creatures neglects
who calls upon Him bring you back my Mary
There is a blank at my left hand that ans only
my Mary up by that thee

8 JanJanuary Monday – Left home riding at dawn.
Got to Carnish abtabout 10 found my watch at the
PPost Office sent from Sandy Macbeans When I
left it the night I was then Rode on to Lmad
dyLochmaddy abtabout 12. Hard frost & road very slipyslippy. AftAfter many
efforts got a boat & off aftafter the packet which
left about 8 or 9. Left abtabout 1 pm. Urquhart
& John Shaw pulled hard against a strong
tide. ExptExpected a to see the packet on the other side
of Airdmaddy Went outside the Maddy
Mōre & on scrutinising the sea in all dirdirections
got a glimpse of the packet throthrough the sleet &
fog close to Skye! Still puldpulled on half inch
to pull all the way to Skye! But the punt begbeing
so small & havghaving no food nor water I mentally thotthought
it better to return – trustgtrusting that the pktpacket may be able
to come & go back tomorrow. Greatly disheartdisheartened
& dispdispleased. Had I got on would be in InvInverness tomortomorrow
night – Got 2 letsletters frfrom Mary seems hurt & my temptemprme
& not getggetting letters. She also sufssuffers for want of letters.
Bingham oil & lantern
9 Tuesday with much diffdifficulty got a boat
to Skye – Calm no packet left at 1pm
ArdmaddyAirdmaddy in a Harris boat 5 years
2 10/- to Portree. Got into Stein abtabout
9pm after a dreaddreadful passage rain
ing & head wind Called at CaptCaptain Mac
donald's Fasach

10 – 1am Left Stein & walkwalked 8 to Dun
vegain hard frost & snow road most
slipslippery Got to DunDunvegain first as the mail gig
was leavleaving 3-45 the only passing Got to Portee
abtabout 8. Called at Mrs Camerons & had some
breakfast. CallCalled at CaptCaptain Carmichael
who was not up Left Portree at 10 Longing
oh! Longing to get to Mary my wife my
darling

MalMalcolm Macinnis Stein watch
to be left with Mr Mitchell Portree
3/- Got an evereverlasting watch key
